text:
1899
Gay Street, north from Waverly Place. At the point where the "Wilson Whiskey" sign board appears, this short thoroughfare veers to the left to meet Christopher Street.  The distinctive building in the background is the Jefferson Market Court.

J. J. Corell, photo
P. L. Sperr Collection

(1)
Gay Street, north from Waverly Place. Gay Street runs only through the block from Waverly Place (originally West 6th Street) to Christopher Street, but the bend in it near the northern end, makes it impossible to see from one end to the other. Gay Street has been spoken of as the shortest street in New York, but it is not -- even Weehawken Street is shorter; however, it is probably
the shortest bent street in Manhattan.
September 25, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, four and a half years later. The new One Christopher Street apartment house, the top of which is seen over the sevenstory loft building in the background, was erected in 1931.
February 24, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
A view showing No's. 12 to 18 Gay Street, four private dwellings
on the west side of this short thoroughfare.

September 4, 1938.

P. L. Sperr.

P. L. Sperr.

(1)
Waverly Place, west from, but not including Gay to Christopher Streets. Prominent building shown, is an apartment house, No. 45 Christopher Street.
May 1, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(2)
The same, slightly westward, showing the triangular Northern Dispensary at Christopher Street.
May 23, 1933.

P. L. Sperr.

(3)
An earlier view of the locality seen in No. 2. Buildings appearing on Christopher Street are Nos. 49 to 41; the 4-story stable being No. 47. These were demolished to form the apartment site shown in later views.
September 24, 1928.

P. L. Sperr.

14 and 16 Gay Street, west side, between Waverly Place and Christopher Street. Scotch weavers inhabited Gay Street over a century ago. About 20 years ago the one-block street had the distinction of being the only Negro street in the Washington Square neighborhood. This photo was reproduced on page 100 of the published volume "Changing New York" from which the above data is an excerpt.

November 16, 1937

Berenice Abbott, photo
Federal Art Project
